articles.title: Why India’s Stated Policy on Hydroxychloroquine Makes No Sense - The Wire
articles.description: The ICMR's reasoning for why it is recommending hydroxychloroquine as prophylaxis to healthcare workers is just unscientific.
articles.content: In a recent video published by ANI, the chief epidemiologist of the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), Raman Gangakhedkar, made a couple of odd statements about hydroxychloroquine. He said that because there was so little evidence of the drug’s effica… [+10162 chars]

articles.title: Coronavirus: How long does it take to recover? - BBC News
articles.description: Recovery from Covid-19 can be a lengthy process, depending on how seriously people get the virus.
articles.content:
Image copyrightGetty Images
Covid-19 only emerged at the end of 2019, but already there are signs it may take a long time for some patients to get back to full health.

articles.title: Death of 42-year-old in Australia shows coronavirus is not an 'old person's disease', say health authorities - SBS News
articles.description: The death of a man in his 40s in Australia shows COVID-19 is not an old person's disease, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Paul Kelly said.
articles.content:
The death of a 42-year old male in Australia reinforces that coronavirus is not an old person's disease, Deputy Chief Medical Officer Paul Kelly has warned.

articles.title: Three million packs of paracetamol from India to replenish British supermarkets shelves - ITV News
articles.description:
After stockpilers emptied paracetamol  from shelves of left British supermarket and retailers, Britain has bought around 3,000,000 packs of paracetamol from India.

The Government ordered the huge amount from India, where the drugs are made, who have approved…

articles.title: Coronavirus pandemic: WHO unsure if antibodies protect against Covid-19 - India Today
articles.description: A WHO's top emergencies expert said that the health organisation is not sure whether the presence of antibodies in blood gives full protection against reinfection with the new coronavirus.
articles.content:
The World Health Organisation (WHO) is not sure whether the presence of antibodies in blood gives full protection against reinfection with the new coronavirus, Mike Ryan, the WHO's top emergencies expert, told a briefing on Friday.

articles.title: University of Oxford could have coronavirus vaccine ready 'by spring' - Sky News Australia
articles.description:
Euronews reporter Trent Murray says the University of Oxford could have a coronavirus vaccine ready early next year. 

The university expected it could have one million doses of the vaccine ready to distribute by spring in the UK.

articles.title: Coronavirus in India: Covid-19 patient who tested negative dies in Kerala - India Today
articles.description: An 85-year-old person, who had tested positive for Covid-19 and later tested negative twice, died due to heart attack early Saturday in Kerala. Health Minister KK Shailaja confirmed that the patient did not die of Covid-19 but other ailments.
articles.content:
